dialogue: Now, hold on. The witness was a few hundred feet away, looking from across the bridge. In the middle of the night, through pouring rain.
I've done landscape work up there. The ridge-line's covered by trees.
Doing my best.
She got a sister?
If Sythe didn't do it, who did?
We don't need to answer that.
So nobody pays for what happened to that girl? I'm not okay with that.
Someone will pay.
How do you know?
Because somebody always does. And I get how you feel, I do, but you can't let feelings sway you.
You don't know anything about me.
How old is your daughter? That's her on your keychain, right?
She turns sixteen in March.
How often do you see her?
Not often enough.
That must be tough.
Like I said, you have no idea.
Not exactly, no. But during the trial, my seat was right in Kendall's parents' eye-line. I saw their pain. And each day I'd ask myself: "What if she were my daughter?"
I'd want justice. Eye for an eye.
Okay. James Sythe's family was also in court each day. His Grandma, his niece. What if he were your son? Wouldn't you want justice for him, too?
I suppose I would, yeah.
Well then?
All right. You got me.
